item.title: Democracy vs Autocracy
item.description: Every group decision falls on a spectrum, from democratic to autocratic. Democratic decisions are derived from consensus, while autocratic decisions are made by a single person. A dictator can be popular as much as a democracy can be tyrannical. Democracy is not inherently good as autocracy is not inherently bad. The success of each style depends on their execution within a context. The Context Autocracy Autocracy has the advantage of efficiency.
item.author: (cam)

item.title: Chrome does some weird stuff if you toggle a stylesheet on and off
item.description: If you re-enable a stylesheet, Chrome may mistakenly try to fetch it again, causing a flash of unstyled content.

item.title: And You Will Know Us by the Company We Keep — Remains of the Day
item.description: It feels as if we're at the tail end of the first era of social media in the West. Looking back at the companies that have survived, certain application architectural choices are ubiquitous. By now, we're all familiar with the infinite vertical scrolling feed of content units, the likes, the follows, the comments, the profile photos and usernames, all those signature design tropes of this Palaeozoic era of social.
item.author: (by Eugene Wei)

What is SSH Tunneling, SSH Reverse Tunneling and SSH Port Forwarding?
item.description: This post explains SSH Tunneling and covers different tunneling features as supported by OpenSSH, which helps achieve security use cases such as remote web service access without exposing port on the internet, accessing server behind NAT, exposing local port to the internet.
